comment.body: Go away spammers.
Awesome, but rather expensive. It had better be actual metal and top notch electronics to justify the asking price.
@Ivesen: you can also edit your reply, then it will take newlines.
Congratulations, Kaffie!
@Kaffie: [A bash script to help you in your quest. myNullPaste.](http://127.0.0.1:43110/17iF64gTLycSohUSJsFyq7FMYsQfMqghJa/?18eGWSaM3Vc9i61LVfogjQJf5gp7EN7b9Y_7)
Yay, instant answers!

@Styromaniac: It seems like it. I don't see a button to navigate there anywhere in my GUI.

EDIT: Ah, next to the New Users column on ZeroMe's front page.
@Border0464fred: So much noise. For someone who grew up in the relative boondocks of >15m drive time on a highway away, this is rather cramped.

Have you tried mountbinds? They are handy things.
```man mount | grep bind``` for info, a handy one that allows only the specified UID and GID to do anything: ```mount  bind PATH/TO/MOUNTED/DIR /path/to/mountpoint 

mount -o remount,umask=077 /path/to/mountpoint/```
@Ivesen: readonly is an option, ```mount -o [other options],ro DEV DIR```

@Ivesen: ...fffffff wrong opts. ```-o "uid=$(id -u zeronet),gid=$(id -g zeronet),rw,umask=077"``` will get you the device mount, then you can bind it elsewhere. This is assuming you have an entire drive dedicated to ZeroNet, because for the life of me I cannot fathom why I went on a bind mount tangent.
@Ivesen: I love you forever.

@Mobile: with how hard China has been cracking down on dissent, that may have been a very wise move on his part; the outrageous, attentions grabbing campaign got eyeballs on whatever he wanted, and he just made the Chinese govt's job much, much harder.
Looking at the default domain name resolver [zite](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/), looks like you need to set up a namecoin node.
Pretty steep dropoff after US. I would have expected Russia to be appearing on the list, given the problems their clearnet has been subjected to.
John Oliver: most trustable news source. This speaks poorly of the actual news outlets.

@Kaffie: Where oh where did you find this mystical chill ISP right in the middle of Hollywood's home state? I suppose it is possible that their proximity has immunized them to the **AA's threats, but good find nonetheless.
@Kaffie: Now that I think about it, California actually has good privacy laws for consumers, which means the ISPs have more legal weaponry than other parts of the world. Makes more sense now.
Swanky, but needs more visible clockpunk.
Jaywalkers... >:(

@U808f: Echoing @Jayofthezero here; net neutrality laws force ISPs to not discriminate on data passing though there networks; it's why it's illegal to throttle BitTorrent traffic, or prevent a reporter's findings dump back to that reporter's HQ. However, due to the language of the law as written, it has not forbidden zero-rating, or the practice of favoring one companies' content over another, such as Netflix being throttled and Hulu being sped up. If net neutrality laws did not exist, then ISPs would be able to choose who got to see what, to an even greater extent than now, up to, including, and past promoting ISP-favored content companies (read: supplicants and extortees) and blocking startups from getting off the ground, further entrenching the ISP's monopoly power. This is why John Oliver did two segments on it, to raise awareness and prevent our corporate overlords from fucking with the connection even more. (YouTube vids, [first](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fpbOEoRrHyU) and [second](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=92vuuZt7wak)). In short, letting corrupt ISPs dictate who passes through when and to whom is a recipe for bribery of ever-higher amounts simply to stay in business, decreased competition in every market and all the effects thereof (higher prices, lower quality, fewer jobs) and preventing innovation of things you've come to take for granted, such as the smartphone in your pocket and cars you drive. Without competion, well, look no further than the set-top box you've been using in your television for the last twenty years; which has changed more, and which is more useful?
If this counts as procrastination, I wonder what you would do if you applied yourself :) Address please?

@Alex (Bwoi): Replicant has the problem of having to write new drivers for hardware, limiting its device roster significantly. Due to no legal incentive, negative or otherwise, to release the source for board support packages on the part of silicon manufacturers, custom ROMs often package proprietary blobs to remain useable. [LineageOS](https://lineageos.org/) is one example of AOSP from source with such blobs. They even have a build tutorial for people who want to examine the source and be assured of the compiled code's non-malice.
...Which update did this come in?
@ulrichard: Well, I know not to boot my Win7 drive until the news propagates...

@Jayofthezero: The fact that Microsloth can do this at all is worrisome. Same kind of deal as when Samsung pushed out an update that bricked Note 7s. The extreme circumstances in both cases prompted this; but as other abuses oh so often widen in scale and depravity after being accepted, so too will these two.
...people actually give their passwords out? What kind of stupidity is this?
@Jayofthezero: Blame? No. The fact that if they so chose they could remotely shut down any Windows box they or any of their supplicants wanted? Much more worrisome. Hence swapping to a Linux distro.

In case one requires more proof Google is pushy: the Google Android app updated with it's Assistant. They keep nagging for you to turn it on and wrap it in a legal click through to get to the disable button. Otherwise the notifications keep coming. While you can filter notifications from a given app, that risks other notifications as collateral damage.
Keyword: ```may```. Don't expect those in power to ever give it up willingly.

@Peponi: [Here you go](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MusicXkuN2pk5hRdmroeyaCLDJtzTicpB). Be warned, there's over 25 GB of music already on there. @Ivesen: the clearnet services have to negotiate licenses with variable terms, and wrongsholders want to extort the services. By contrast, ZeroMusic is everyone putting their music in a big list and hitting the random button. No headaches, no negotiations, just music. ZM could use a shuffled/random play in downloaded files feature, and shuffled/random files in entire site, downloading when needed.
You trust your private key to a proxy? This seems like a silly course of action.
